IN THE MATTER OF THE PETITION OF 
MINNESOTA POWER FOR ACQUISITION 
OF ALLETE BY CANADA PENSION 
PLAN INVESTMENT BOARD AND 
GLOBAL INFRASTRUCTURE PARTNERS 
  
SUPPLEMENTAL FILING  
 
MPUC Docket No. E015/PA-24-198  
 
On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power1 filed with the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission 
(the “Commission”) its Petition for Approval of the Acquisition of the Company by entities 
controlled or managed by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global 
Infrastructure Management, LLC (which operates under the trading name Global Infrastructure 
Partners or “GIP”)2 (GIP and CPP Investments together, the “Partners”) through a new Partner-
created entity known as Alloy Parent LLC (“Parent”) (the “Acquisition”). The Minnesota 
Department of Commerce, Division of Energy Resources (“Department”) filed comments in this 
proceeding on August 19, 2024, requesting, as relevant here, that the Commission require 
Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition by November 1, 2024, based on the then-pending 
 
1 As the Commission is aware, Minnesota Power is a regulated operating division of ALLETE, Inc. Throughout this 
Petition, we use “Minnesota Power” to refer to this regulated utility operating in Minnesota.  Unless otherwise 
specifically defined, references to “ALLETE” indicate ALLETE, Inc., which is the entire enterprise including 
Minnesota Power and all regulated and non-regulated subsidiaries.  “The Company” is a more general reference to 
ALLETE, Inc. d/b/a Minnesota Power.   
2 Global Infrastructure Management, LLC is a global independent infrastructure fund advisor that operates under the 
trading name GIP and provides investment management services and advice to various GIP funds.  These GIP funds, 
including GIP Fund V, indirectly hold investments in portfolio companies that own infrastructure assets.  As further 
explained herein, on October 1, 2024, BlackRock, Inc. acquired the fund advisor Global Infrastructure Management, 
LLC, but the management team of GIP continues to manage the key strategic direction, operations, and activities of 
the GIP funds themselves. 
2 
 acquisition of Global Infrastructure Management, LLC by BlackRock, Inc. (“BlackRock” and the 
“BlackRock Transaction”),3 to include the following information: 
a. A detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain 
interests in GIP by BlackRock requires Commission authorization under 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, and if not, why not; 
b. All additional information required to comply with the filing 
requirements under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 
7825.1800 with respect to the pending acquisition of certain interests in 
GIP by BlackRock; 
c. A discussion of affiliated interest issues that may arise between 
ALLETE and companies held directly or indirectly in the portfolios of 
CPP Investments or BlackRock.4 
At the Commission’s September 19, 2024, meeting, the Commission approved the Department’s 
request but required Minnesota Power to supplement its Petition with the above information by 
October 8, 2024. Accordingly, Minnesota Power supplements its Petition as follows: 
A. A Detailed Explanation of Whether the Acquisition of Certain Interests in Global 
Infrastructure Management, LLC by Blackrock, Inc. Requires Commission 
Authorization Under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 (2023), and if Not, Why Not 
The BlackRock acquisition of the equity interests in Global Infrastructure Management, 
LLC is not subject to Commission approval under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, as (1) neither BlackRock 
nor GIP is a “public utility” subject to the Commission’s approval jurisdiction; (2) GIP, not 
BlackRock, is managing a 40 percent ownership interest in ALLETE, held by GIP Fund V, and 
managing a 20 percent interest held by Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P. (“Tower 
Bridge”)5; (3) GIP is not directly acquiring a majority interest in the operating systems or units of 
the Minnesota Power public utility under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1600 and 
.1700; and (4) the Commission has ample opportunity to evaluate GIP’s acquisition of a partial

1. The BlackRock Transaction. 
As further described in subsection (C) below, BlackRock is a publicly traded (NYSE: 
BLK) investment management firm domiciled in the United States that provides investment 
management services to its mutual funds, investment accounts, and other investment funds.  These 
services include the purchase, sale, and voting regarding voting securities on behalf of investment 
funds and investment accounts, including the voting securities of public utilities and utility holding 
companies. The sole business of BlackRock and its subsidiaries is the provision of investment 
management and related services.  No shareholder or affiliated group of shareholders owns or 
controls 10 percent or more of BlackRock’s common stock.  
GIP, which is the trading name of Global Infrastructure Management, LLC, is an 
infrastructure investment management firm headquartered in New York City that specializes in 
investing in, owning, and operating assets within the energy, transport, digital infrastructure and 
water and waste management sectors.  As of the consummation of the BlackRock Transaction on 
October 1, 2024, BlackRock indirectly owns and controls6 the general partnerships that control 
each GIP-sponsored investment fund and managed account, including GIP Fund V and Tower 
Bridge, which hold, indirectly, equity investments in portfolio companies that own infrastructure 
assets.  Notwithstanding the indirect control, and as stated in the Petition, the strategic and day-to-
 
6 Statements about control herein are solely intended to conform to the way the Federal Energy Regulatory

Management, LLC are not limited to rights associated with FERC’s passive investor precedent.  See, e.g.,  AES 
Creative Resources, L.P. et al., 129 FERC ¶ 61,239 (2009);  Ad Hoc Renewable Energy Fin. Grp. , 161 FERC ¶ 61,010 
(2017).  
4 
 day operations and activities of GIP will continue to be organized and managed by the current 
management team of GIP, separately from BlackRock, and investment decisions of GIP-managed 
funds will continue to be made by the investment committee of the respective fund. The voting 
members of the investment committee of GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge are also GIP personnel.  
Similarly, while GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge have a partial, indirect interest in Parent that 
provides GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge (along with CPP Investments) with certain decision-
making authority over the ALLETE board of directors, the strategic and day-to-day operations and 
activities of ALLETE will continue to be managed separately from GIP. Additionally, as explained 
in the Petition, GIP’s managed funds are making the indirect investment in Parent and that interest 
is divided between GIP Fund V (40 percent) and Tower Bridge (20 percent). As such, GIP would 
not have direct ownership or control over the day-to-day operations of ALLETE following 
consummation of the Acquisition. Further, as noted above, BlackRock does not have control over 
the strategic and day-to-day operations and activities of GIP, much less those of ALLETE. 
2. BlackRock and GIP are Not Public Utilities. 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 states that “No public utility  shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any 
plant as an operating unit or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, 
or merge or consolidate with another public utility  or transmission company operating in this state, 
without first being authorized so to do by the commission.”7 Under Minnesota law, a “public 
utility” is defined (with certain inapplicable exceptions) as “persons, corporations, or other legal 
entities, their lessees, trustees, and receivers, now or hereafter operating, maintaining, or 
controlling in this state equipment or facilities  for furnishing at retail natural, manufactured, or 
 
7 Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, subd. 1 (emphasis added). 
5 
 mixed gas or electric service to or for the public or engaged in the production and retail sale 
thereof.”8  
Notably, both the statute and the rule applicable to transactions speak to the entity 
controlling the equipment or facilities providing the electric service, such as Minnesota Power, 
rather than the upstream owners of the holding company in which the public utility resides. Many 
statutes within Minnesota’s regulatory construct depend on the public utility being the entity that 
controls the equipment or facilities providing electric or gas service; otherwise, the Commission 
would be regulating the rates, services, service standards, and policies9 of any entity with a 
financial interest in a public utility regardless of whether that entity in fact provides utility service. 
This would be effectively impossible for the Commission to execute, could lead to unreasonable 
and unintended results, and therefore would be an unreasonable interpretation of the applicable 
laws and rules.   
Rather, consistent with Minnesota law, the Commission has never considered or treated a 
public utility holding company, much less the investors in a public utility holding company, as a 
regulated public utility. For example, while Minnesota Power is a division of ALLETE, the 
Commission regulates the Minnesota Power operating utility; the Commission does not regulate 
the unregulated subsidiaries of ALLETE or the affiliates of Minnesota Power directly. In other 
merger dockets, the Commission has also explicitly identified public utility holding companies as 
holding companies even if they had a subsidiary public utility.10 Moreover, public utility holding

9 See, e.g. , Minn. Stat. § 216B.09, subds. 2, 3.

CONDITIONS  (Mar. 24, 1997); In the Matter of the Proposed Merger of Midwest Energy, Inc. and Iowa Resources, 
Inc.; In the Matter of the Proposed Merger of Iowa Public Service Company and Iowa Power, Inc. , Docket No. G-
010/DI-90-1144; G-010/PA-91-728, O RDER APPROVING MERGERS AND REQUIRING FURTHER FILINGS  (Jan. 21, 1992). 
6 
 companies are only indirectly regulated in relation to the public utility, through Minnesota’s 
affiliated interest laws and rules.11 There would be no need for such laws and rules if public utility 
holding companies were in fact public utilities such that the Commission regulated them directly. 
Similarly, Minnesota Rules govern when and how a transaction involving a public utility 
(in this case, Minnesota Power) requires approval under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50.  Minn. R. 
7825.1600, Subp.7 defines a “transaction” as “the consummation of a transfer of property, of a 
merger, of a consolidation.” Minn. R. 7825.1600, Subps. 2 and 4 define a consolidation as “the 
combination of assets and liabilities of a public utility with another public utility” and “merger” as 
“the acquisition of the assets or the assets and liabilities of the equity securities of a public utility 
by a public utility.” In contrast, Minn. R.  7825.1600, Subp. 8 defines a transfer of property as “the 
sale or acquisition of an operating unit or system...”; i.e., something different than a merger or 
consolidation. If a purchasing entity became a “public utility” simply by virtue of the acquisition 
of a public utility or public utility holding company, then every transaction would be a merger or 
consolidation, and there would be no need for a separate discussion of a “transaction” in Minn. 
Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1600 that does not involve a public utility on both sides of the 
transaction.  
Finally, as described by Staff in Briefing Papers ahead of the Commission’s September 19, 
2024, weekly agenda meeting on this matter, there are significant practical concerns with 
interpreting Minnesota law to expand the Commission’s jurisdiction to apply to institutional 
investors such as BlackRock, GIP, and CPP Investments. For example, Staff noted the challenges 
associated with the Department’s interpretation of affiliated interests to include all holdings of 
BlackRock and the Partners. Specifically, given the nature of BlackRock and its numerous non-
 
11 See Minn. Stat. § 216B.48. 
7 
 controlled holdings, as well as the fact that BlackRock owns non-controlling, public shares in 
Commission-regulated utilities other than Minnesota Power, the Department’s interpretation 
would result in virtually every contract that Minnesota’s investor-owned utilities execute 
becoming affiliated interest contracts, which would put immense strain on the Commission’s 
resources and would be virtually impossible for the Commission to administer. Accordingly, 
treating institutional investors such as BlackRock, GIP, and CPP Investments, as well as their 
portfolio company holdings, as “public utilities” subject to the Commission’s full regulatory 
authority would result in an even more impossible situation. 
3. BlackRock’s Acquisition of Interests in GIP is Not a Separate Purchase of 
Public Utility Property under Minnesota Law.  
As entities even further attenuated from the public utility than the utility holding company, 
entities investing in infrastructure funds that in turn invest in holding companies of public utility 
holding companies does not equate to a transaction involving the “sale or acquisition of an 
operating unit or system”; rather, it is an acquisition of an equity interest in the holding company 
several levels above the holding company of the public utility.  Minn. R. 7825.1700, authorized 
by Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, requires a public utility to receive Commission approval before entering 
into a “transaction,” defined as “the consummation of a transfer of property , of a merger, or of a 
consolidation.”12 As noted above, “transfer of property” means “the sale or acquisition of an 
operating unit or system.”13 A finding that BlackRock’s ownership of equity interests in Global 
Infrastructure Management, LLC constitutes a “transaction” would not only ignore the rule’s 
requirement that the transfer involve “an operating unit or system” (as opposed to equity interests), 
but it would also broaden the rule’s meaning such that any transaction anywhere in the chain of 
 
12 Minn. R. 7825.1600, Subp. 7 (emphasis added). 
13 Minn. R. 7825.1600, Subp. 8. 
8 
 ownership of the public utility, no matter how far removed, would require Commission approval. 
This interpretation would be exceedingly difficult for the Commission to administer and would 
result in extreme outcomes. 
More specifically, financial investors in a public utility holding company, such as GIP 
Fund V, BlackRock, or CPP Investments ( e.g., investors in Parent to ALLETE), are even further 
removed from the public utility than the holding company itself. For example, the Commission 
does not consider the current public shareholders of ALLETE, which would already include 
BlackRock, to be “public utilities” under Minnesota law. While both public shareholders and 
private investors in a public utility holding company select and approve the board of directors for 
the holding company, neither the public shareholders nor the private investors manage the day-to-
day operations of the Commission-regulated public utility or the equipment or facilities providing 
service. In turn, the shareholders of the public utility holding company are often institutional 
investors, and in turn, these investors may have further upstream passive investors. These investors 
are increasingly removed from the public utility and again maintain only an economic interest, 
rather than an operating interest, in the Commission-regulated public utility. Similarly, the 
upstream investors in GIP Fund V and Tower Bridge are significantly attenuated from Minnesota 
Power’s operations and functions.  Further, as noted above, BlackRock does not have control over 
the strategic and day-to-day operations and activities of GIP, much less those of ALLETE.  
Accordingly, for each of these reasons, Commission approval of the BlackRock 
Transaction is not required. 
4. The Commission Will Have Adequate Information to Evaluate BlackRock’s 
Role in the Acquisition. 
As detailed above, BlackRock’s acquisition of equity interests in Global Infrastructure 
Management, LLC does not require Commission approval, as it does not involve public utilities 
9 
 subject to the Commission’s jurisdiction, and it is not a transaction for “the sale or acquisition of 
an operating unit or system.” Reading Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and the relevant Minnesota Rules so 
as to require Commission approval of this acquisition would lead to the impracticable situation of 
needing Commission approval for any acquisition, no matter how remotely related to a public 
utility, including certain fluctuations in BlackRock’s public shareholders. This would impose a 
significant, unworkable administrative burden on the Commission. 
However, if the Commission determines that such approval is required under Minn. Stat. 
§ 216B.50 as implemented by Minnesota Rules, the Commission should grant a variance from 
Minn. R. 7825.1600, Subps. 7-8 (applying the definitions of “transaction” and “transfer of 
property”) and Minn. R. 7825.1700 (requiring approval for a transaction).  Given that the 
Commission will already be assessing the overall GIP ownership as they pertain to Minnesota 
Power, including affiliates as applicable, it is not necessary to interpret the Minnesota Rules in a 
manner that may have unintended future consequences in order to evaluate this particular 
transaction.  To the extent the Commission determines a variance is potentially beneficial or 
necessary to reach this conclusion, such a variance is requested for the reasons set forth in the 
Petition. 
Finally, the Commission will have the information necessary to approve the BlackRock 
Transaction as part of this proceeding if the Commission determines that such approval is required 
because the information provided in Minnesota Power’s Petition seeking approval of the ALLETE 
Acquisition is fundamentally the same as the information that would be required if Minnesota 
Power were seeking approval of the Acquisition and the BlackRock Transaction together, as 
discussed in Section B, below.14 Moreover, the parties to the Acquisition have committed to ring-

Canada Pension Plain Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners  (No. E015/PA-24-198).

 fencing provisions in the Merger Agreement and expressed an openness to discussing relevant 
additional affiliated interest considerations. Additionally, there is ample time to develop any issues 
related to the BlackRock Transaction in this proceeding, as the contested case process is not yet 
underway. The parties will be able to present and defend their positions in testimony and at an 
evidentiary hearing and will be able to conduct discovery on any relevant issues. Accordingly, 
BlackRock’s acquisition of equity interests in Global Infrastructure Management, LLC should not 
delay or change this proceeding, and approval of that acquisition can be adequately handled in this 
case, should the Commission deem approval to be necessary. 
B. All Additional Information Required to Comply with the Filing Requirements Under 
Minn. Stat. § 216b.50 (2023) and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800 (2023) With 
Respect to the Acquisition of Certain Interests in Global Infrastructure Partners by 
Blackrock, Inc. 
On August 26, 2024, Minnesota Power filed reply comments, which, among other things, 
addressed whether Minnesota Power’s Petition complied with all filing requirements under Minn. 
Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800, including the Department’s request for 
additional information regarding the application of the statute and rules to BlackRock’s acquisition 
of equity interests in Global Infrastructure Management, LLC. In response to the Department’s 
request, Attachment A to Minnesota Power’s reply comments discussed how, if at all, the data 
responsive to the statute and rules pertained to upstream investors in the Partners. That information 
is likewise provided as Attachment A to this Supplemental Filing. 
C. A Discussion of Affiliated Interest Issues That May Arise Between ALLETE and 
Companies Held Directly or Indirectly in the Portfolios of Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board or Blackrock, Inc. 
In this Supplemental Filing, Minnesota Power and the Partners provide a discussion of how 
Minnesota’s affiliated interest law15 relates to the proposed Acquisition, and information about 
 
15 Minn. Stat. § 216B.48. 
11 
 how the requirements relate to GIP and CPP Investments, as well as BlackRock (none of whom 
will be direct owners of ALLETE).  This is a matter of first impression for the Commission but is 
informed by the Commission’s past practices and statutory obligations. The Commission need not 
make any final determinations regarding affiliated interests at this time, since no affiliated interests 
will arise until the closing of the proposed Acquisition (and even then, would only implicate 
contracts entered into after the closing). Rather, the Commission has the opportunity to use this 
proceeding to gather information and to identify procedures and requirements that can be applied 
going forward to ensure that the Commission continues to have the information it needs to exercise 
its oversight on behalf of Minnesota Power’s customers.  Minnesota Power and the Partners look 
forward to working with the Commission and other stakeholders in this effort.   
1. The Commission’s Regulatory Authority, Including over Affiliated Interest 
Agreements, Is Unchanged by the Proposed Acquisition.  
a. The Commission’s Regulatory Authority Is Not Solely Predicated on 
the Affiliated Interest Statute. 
The affiliated interest statute needs to be interpreted consistent with the Commission’s core 
responsibility to establish just and reasonable rates.16 In this effort, the Commission reviews the 
costs of providing service,17 including review of costs incurred under contracts and review of all 
contracts for customer-specific rates, terms or service conditions.18 These responsibilities, and the 
Commission’s authority to carry them out, are not limited by or predicated upon the affiliated 
interest statute. Put another way, the affiliated interest statute is not the sole, nor even the primary, 
tool used by the Commission to make sure Minnesota customers receive “adequate and reliable 
services at reasonable rates.”19 Rather, it is a targeted provision that requires approval of certain 
 
16 Minn. Stat. § 216B.03. 
17 Minn. Stat. § 216B.16, subd. 6. 
18 Minn. Stat. § 216B.05, subd. 2a. 
19 Minn. Stat. § 216B.01. 
12 
 contracts with a value of more than $50,00020 as a means of preventing self-dealing that could 
benefit entities that have common ownership in a way that would harm customers.  As discussed 
below, the affiliated interest statute has been applied in this manner for many years.   
b. Affiliated Interest Review Applies to Agreements Entered Into After 
the Acquisition is Completed, not Existing Contracts or the Acquisition 
Agreements. 
The affiliated interest law requires approval of contracts with a value greater than $50,000 
between a public utility and an affiliated interest.  This approval does not extend to existing 
agreements between ALLETE and Partner entities because existing contracts between ALLETE 
and the Partners (or BlackRock), if there are any, were negotiated prior to the existence of any 
affiliate relationship and therefore presumably at arms-length.  As set out above, the Department’s 
contrary position in Initial Comments in this proceeding,21 should it be pursued during or after this 
proceeding, would impose unworkable regulatory burdens without benefit and should be rejected. 
c. The Commission’s Historical Approach Has Recognized Limits to 
Application of the Affiliated Interest Statute. 
Additionally, institutional investors like BlackRock and Vanguard have, for many years, 
owned 5 percent or more of the voting securities of Minnesota public utilities or holding companies 
owning Minnesota public utilities.  Examples include not only BlackRock’s present ownership of 
ALLETE, Xcel Energy, and Otter Tail Corporation,22 but also Vanguard, through its various funds, 
owning more than 5 percent of the shares of ALLETE, MDU Resources Group, CenterPoint

21 Department Comments at 6 (“It is the Department’s understanding that if both transactions close, all of those 
companies would become affiliates of ALLETE and any contract or agreement ALLETE or Minnesota Power has 
now or in the future would become an affiliated interest agreement requiring Commission approval.”) (emphasis 
added). 
22 Staff Briefing Papers at 21; SEC Form SC 13G/A (Beneficial Ownership Report) showing BlackRock’s ownership

Corporation (Jan. 22, 2024).

 Energy, and Xcel Energy.23  In no instance has the Commission concluded that other businesses 
in which BlackRock or Vanguard own similar interests are affiliates of Minnesota public utilities 
merely due to the common ownership by BlackRock or Vanguard.  And that result is entirely 
appropriate, because the contrary interpretation proffered by the Department24 would turn 
innumerable publicly traded companies into affiliates of each Minnesota public utility,25 an absurd 
result that would not protect against affiliate self-dealing and is entirely unworkable—for the 
Commission and for the utilities the Commission regulates.  Minnesota law does not support such 
a result.26 
d. The Public Interest is Best Served by a Reasonable Reading of the 
Affiliated Interest Statute. 
In addition to being a reasonable reading of a complex statute and supported by the 
Commission’s past practice, the interpretation set out above can be implemented in a way that 
enables the Commission to carry out its responsibility to ensure just and reasonable rates without 
incurring additional, unworkable burdens.  Thus, this approach can further the public interest in an 
efficient regulatory process while still providing protection for the interests of Minnesotans. 
A reasonable application of the affiliated interest statute is necessary in a modern 
marketplace where investments of the size and scope needed by a public utility are regularly made 
through multi-tiered investment structures that are able to utilize capital of numerous investors but 
do not give all of those investors control of the utility. For example, while the affiliated interest 
 
23 Staff Briefing Papers at 20-21; FERC Docket EC19-57, Quarterly Report of The Vanguard Group, Inc., et al.  
(08/13/2024). 
24 Staff Briefing Papers at 9; Department Comments at 5-6. 
25 BlackRock and Vanguard ownership percentage from Yahoo!Finance www.finance.yahoo.com  on August 30, 2024 
(Department Comments at 21, n. 14). 
26 Minn. Stat. §645.16 (“The object of all interpretation and construction of laws is to ascertain and effectuate the 
intention of the legislature.”); Minn. Stat. §645.17 (“In ascertaining the intention of the legislature the courts may be 
guided by the following presumptions: (1) the legislature does not intend a result that is absurd, impossible of 
execution, or unreasonable….”). 
14 
 statute can be an effective tool to protect the public from harm that may result from self-dealing 
among related companies, it does not follow that affiliated interest scrutiny needs to apply where 
there is a lack of direct control over the contracting company or companies, whether it be the utility 
or its counterparties.  Put another way, if there is not an ability on the part of an investor to directly 
control the contracting decisions of an entity, that entity’s contracts will be entered into at arms-
length relative to other interests of the investor, and the concerns of self-dealing are not present. 
This principle is true for non-controlled, minority investments by both GIP and CPP Investments.  
For example, as explained in the Petition and Reply Comments, CPP Investments has an 
investment-only mandate, and also does not always have information rights with respect to such 
non-controlled portfolio companies.  Accordingly, CPP Investments is often not able to identify, 
let alone control or direct, the contracting of its non-controlled portfolio companies.  GIP Fund V, 
which will invest indirectly in ALLETE pursuant to the proposed Acquisition, also does not 
typically have information rights with respect to the investments of other GIP funds and has no 
ability to direct their contracting decisions.  Consequently, as with CPP Investments, the 
transactions are already insulated from affiliate concerns.  The same and additional limitations 
apply in the case of BlackRock, as a publicly held company with the reporting and fiduciary 
obligations typical of public companies.  
Application of the affiliated interest statute in the manner outlined above, combined with 
the Commission’s ongoing authority over contracts entered into by Minnesota Power and the costs 
incurred and recovered in connection with the same, can ensure that the Commission has the 
information it needs to provide for just and reasonable rates.  This kind of balancing furthers the 
public interest in an efficient regulatory process while avoiding the regulatory burden and costs 
that would flow from an unnecessarily broad and factually unworkable interpretation. 
15 
 2. The Commission Can Continue to Evaluate Affiliated Interests Going Forward. 
Under Minn. R. 7825.2200, Minnesota Power is required to file with the Commission each 
year certain information regarding its affiliated interests.  As it has done for many years, Minnesota 
Power will continue to disclose and address its affiliated interests in that filing.  In Direct 
Testimony, Minnesota Power will discuss any potential adjustment of these filings or procurement 
protocols for consideration and implementation by the Commission upon approval of the 
Acquisition.  Minnesota Power aims to ensure that regulatory and non-regulatory ring-fencing 
remains robust, and to continue the dialogue regarding appropriate arrangements for the protection 
of Minnesota Power’s customers.

Additional Info: ORDER REQUIRING ADDITIONAL INFORMATION AND GRANTING INTERVENTION, AND NOTICE OF AND ORDER FOR HEARING
content:
1 
 BEFORE THE MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSION  
 
  
Katie J. Sieben  Chair  
Hwikwon Ham  Commissioner  
Valerie Means  Commissioner  
Joseph K. Sullivan  Commissioner  
John A. Tuma  Commissioner  
  
  
  
In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota 
Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by  
Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and 
Global Infrastructure Partners  ISSUE DATE: October 7, 2024  
 
DOCKET NO.  E-015/PA -24-198 
 
ORDER  REQUIRING ADDITIONAL 
INFORMATION AND GRANTING 
INTERVENTION, AND NOTICE OF 
AND ORDER FOR HEARING  
 
 
PROCEDURAL HISTORY  
 
On May 5, 2024, ALLETE, Inc. ( ALLETE ), owner of Minnesota Power, entered into a n 
agreement to be acquired by  entities controlled by the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board 
(CPP Investments) and Global Infrastructure Partners (GIP ). 
 
On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power filed a petition seeking Commission approval for the 
proposed transaction pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 . The petition included a copy of the  
May 5, 2024 agreement.  
 
By September  19, 2024, various entities had filed comments , reply comments, and /or petitions to 
intervene  in this matter —including t he following:  
 
• Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota (CUB)  
• Ratepayer Gayle Claesson  
• CURE  
• Energy Cents Coalition (ECC)  
• Large Power Intervenors (LPI)  
• Minnesota Department of Commerce (Department)  
• Minnesota Office of the Attorney General  (OAG)  
• Minnesota Power  
• International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local No. 31  (IBEW)  
• Laborers’ International Union of North America —Minnesota & North Dakota (LIUNA)  
• Operating Engineers Local 49 and North Central States Regional Council of Carpenters  
 
2 
 On September 19, 2024,  Minnesota Power’s petition  came before the Commission.  
 
 
FINDINGS AND CON CLUSIONS  
 
I. Summary  
 
The Commission will decline to grant o r deny Minnesota Power’s petition at this time. Instead, 
the Commission will direct Minnesota Power to supplement its petition  and will refer this matter 
the Office of Administrative Hearings for contested case proceedings to develop the relevant 
facts of this matter, including addressing a list of questions discussed below.  
 
The Commission will also take steps to facilitate the Department’s efforts to secure specialized 
technical assistance in analyzing this matter.  
 
Finally, the Commission will grant intervention to all parties that have requested it so far . 
 
II. Jurisdiction  
 
Minnesota law bars anyone from transferring assets related to a public utility worth more than 
$1 million without first applying for and receiving permission from the Commission.  
 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 , Restrictions on Property Transfer and Merger , states:  
 
Subdivision 1.  Commission approval required.  No public 
utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit 
or system in this state for a total consideration in excess of 
$1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with another public utility or 
transmission company operating in this s tate, without first being 
authorized so to do by the commission. Upon the filing of an 
application for the approval and consent of the commission, the 
commission shall investigate, with or without public hearing.  The 
commission shall hold a public hearing, upon such notice as the 
commission may require. If the commission finds that the proposed 
action is consistent with the public interest, it shall give its consent 
and approval by order in writing. In reaching it s determination, the 
commission shall take into consideration the reasonable value of the 
property, plant, or securities to be acquired or disposed of, or merged 
and consolidated.  
 
This section does not apply to the purchase of property to 
replace or add to the plant of the public utility by construction.  
 
  
 
3 
 Minn. R. 7825.1700 , Procedure for Approval to Acquire Property , states:  
 
A public utility, prior to entering into a transaction, shall 
petition for and receive from the commission by formal written 
order approval for such transaction. A petition for approval of 
capital structure (parts 7825.1000 to 7825.1500) shall be filed 
concurrently with the petition for  approval of transfer, merger, or 
consolidation if consideration for such a transaction is a security or 
securities as defined in part 7825.1000. The commission may 
require an independent valuation of the property involved in  the 
transaction.  
 
Minn. R. 7825.1800 , Filing Requirements for Petitions to Acquire Property , states:  
 
Petitions for approval to acquire property shall contain … the 
following information, either in the petition or as exhibits attached 
thereto:  
 
A. Petitions for approval of a merger or of a consolidation 
shall be accompanied by the following: the petition signed by all 
parties; all information, for each public utility, as required in parts 
7825.1400 and 7825.1500; the detailed reasons of the petit ions and 
each party for entering into the proposed transaction, and all facts 
warranting the same; the full terms and conditions of the proposed 
merger or consolidation.  
 
B. Petitions for approval of a transfer of property shall be 
accompanied by the following: all information as required in part 
7825.1400, items A to J; the agreed upon purchase price and the 
terms for payment and other considerations.  
 
C. A description of the property involved in the transaction 
including any franchises, permits, or operative rights, and the 
original cost of such property, individually or by class, the 
depreciation and amortization reserves applicable to such property, 
individually or by class. If the original cost is unknown, an estimate 
shall be made of such cost. A detailed description of the method and 
all supporting documents used in such estimate shall be submitted.  
 
D. Other pertinent facts or additional information that the 
commission may require.  
 
 
  
 
4 
 III. The Petition  
 
A. Parties to the Transaction  
 
1. CPP Investments  
 
Minnesota Power reports that CPP Investments  manages the Canada Pension Plan Fund  but 
operates independently of any governmental entity. CPP Investments has announced plans to 
eliminate the net emission of greenhouse gasses from its operations by 2050. CPP Investments 
has already acquired an interest in Puget Sound Energy, the largest electric and gas utility in the 
state of Washington, which has allowed that utility to accelerate its own plans to reduce 
greenhouse gas  emissions.  
 
2. GIP 
 
While GIP owns firms in many sectors of the economy, Minnesota Power reports that GIP aspires 
to be one of the world’s leading owners, developers, and operators of renewable energy assets.  
 
BlackRock , Inc. (BlackRock) , one of America’s largest financial management companies,  has 
announced plans to buy  GIP. According to Minnesota Power, GIP anticipates continuing to 
manage the various funds under its control, including the funds invested in ALLETE , after 
Blackrock’s acquisition . 
 
B. Proposed Transaction  
 
According to Minnesota Power, CPP Investments and GIP plan to  form a new corporation, Alloy 
Parent LLC, to acquire all of ALLETE’s shares and interests. This would result in CPP 
Investments indirectly owning 40 percent of ALLETE’s outstanding common stock —and GIP 
indirectly own ing 60 percent through two funds: Global Infrastructure Partners V (GIP Fund V) 
and Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, L.P. (Tower Bridge). The resulting organizational 
structure would look as follows:  
  
 
5 
 Figure 1: Post -Acquisition Organizational Structure1 
                      
            
 
 
Minnesota Power estimates that the transaction w ould cost the new partners approximately 
$6.2 billion —$3.9 billion to purchase ALLETE shares and $2.3 billion of assumed ALLETE  
debt.   
 
According to Minnesota Power, this acquisition would  result in a few changes to its operations. 
The largest change would be in providing the utility with a better source of funding to facilitate 
efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emission . Also, t he partners propose to refinance some of 
ALLETE ’s and Minnesota Power’s debt —but Minnesota Power states that this would have no 
financial effect on ratepayers , and that there is no plan to borrow money related to this 
transaction . Finally,  following the transaction the new entity would propose a formula for 
allocating tax costs among the various levels of the new organization.   
 
But in other respects, Minnesota Power’s operations would continue as before. ALLETE  would 
remain a stand -alone company with its own board of directors with the same fiduciary 
obligations and oversight responsibilities as before, and would have the same relationship with 
Minnesota Power and the Commission as before . Moreover, the merger agreement includes a 
variety of commitments to maintain the status quo, including the following:  
 
 
1 Minnesota Power petition, at 11 (July 19, 2024).  Note that BlackRock also proposes to acquire GIP.  

 
6 
 • Maintaining ALLETE ’s headquarters in Duluth , Minnesota . 
• Maintaining the “ALLETE” and “Minnesota Power” names.  
• Honoring union contracts and maintaining long -standing practices with respect to the 
unionization of contractors.  
• Maintaining employment for non -union employees for at least two years.  
• Maintaining the current senior management team in the normal course of business, with 
local management retaining authority to make decisions for Minnesota Power subject to 
board oversight.  
• Guaranteeing that at least one member of the ALLETE board w ould be from Minnesota, 
one from Wisconsin, and two independent  board members .  
• Maintaining t he board’s authority to approve budgets , including capital budgets . 
• Maintaining historic levels of economic development and charitable contributions in the 
service territories of ALLETE and its s ubsidiaries . 
• Forgoing any attempt to recover any acquisition premium or transaction costs from 
customers.  
• Using all  commercially reasonable efforts to maintain Minnesota Power’s debt/equity 
ratios and corporate and facility ratings in accordance with regulatory requirements.  
• Maintaining the overall scope and resources that Minnesota Power dedicate s to 
affordability programs , and recognizing the Commission ’s authority to approve, reject or 
modify any changes to these  programs . 
• Continuing  to provide access to Minnesota Power’s books, records, and information.  
 
IV. Jurisdiction and Commission Action  
 
The Commission finds that it has jurisdiction over the matter set forth in Minnesota Power’s 
petition pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and relevant rules.  Having considered the arguments of 
the petitioner and the commenters, the Commission finds that it lacks a sufficient factual record to 
either grant or deny the petition. Accordingly, the Commission will take the following steps.  
 
A. Supplementing the Record  Regarding BlackRock’s Proposal  
 
First, BlackRock ’s proposal to acquire GIP arose after Minnesota Power’s initial filing, and this 
matter has not been as well developed as other matters in this docket . To remedy this, the 
Commission will direct Minnesota Power to supplement its petition to include the following 
information:  
 
1. A detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain 
interests in GIP by BlackRock requires Commission authorization under 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, and if not, why not . 
 
2. All additional information required to comply with the filing requirements 
under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800 with 
respect to the pending acquisition of certain interests in GIP by BlackRock .  
 
 
 
7 
 3. A discussion of affiliated interest issues that may arise between ALLETE  
and companies held directly or indirectly in the portfolios of CPP 
Investment s or BlackRock.  
 
Minnesota Power states that it can provide this information by October 8, 2024 . The Commission 
accepts this proposal.  
 
B. Facilitating the Department’s Retention of Technical Assistance  
 
Second, given the complexity of the matters set forth in the petition and the comments, the 
Department asks the Commission to support its efforts to secure technical assistance in 
reviewing this matter. Minnesota Power, among others, supports this proposal .  
 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.62, subd. 8 , states in relevant part as follows:  
 
If the commission  … determines that it is necessary, in order to carry 
out its duties imposed under this chapter or chapter 216, 216A, 
216E, 216F, or 216G, to conduct an investigation or audit of any 
public utility operations, practices, or policies requiring specialized 
technical professional investigative services for the inquiry, the 
commission may request the commissioner of commerce to seek 
authority from the commissioner of management and budget to 
incur costs reasonably attributable to the specialized services. If the 
investigation or audit is approved by the commissioner of 
management and budget, the commissioner of commerce shall carry 
out the investigation in the manner directed by the commission …. 
 
The Commission finds that it is necessary, in order to carry out its duties under Minnesota 
Statutes chapter 216B  to review the sale of utility assets exceeding $1 million, to investigate  
Minnesota Power’s operations, practices, and/or policies, and that this investigation will require 
specialized technical professional investigative services . Accordingly,  the Commission will ask 
the Commissioner of the Department of Commerce to seek authority from the Commissioner of 
the Department of Management and Budget  to incur costs reasonably attributable to securing 
those services.  
 
C. Referring for Contested Case Proceedings  
 
Third , when a proceeding involves contested material facts and there is a right to a hearing under 
statute or rule, or if the Commission finds that all significant issues have not been resolved to its 
satisfaction, the Commission refers the matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for 
contested case proceedings.2 Because significant issues remain unresolved, the Commission will 
refer the matter  to that office  and ask that t he Administrative Law Judge  assigned to this matter 
 
2 Minn. R. 7829.1000.  
 
8 
 conduct hearings as described in this order and file a report and recommendation with the 
Commission.  
 
The Commission requests  that the Administrative Law Judge  issue the report no later than  
July 15, 2025, or earlier  in the event of a settlement . Following receipt of the Administrative 
Law Judge’s report and recommendation, the Commission will proceed to make its final decision 
in accordance with Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and relevant rules.  
V. Issues to be Addressed  
The Commission expects that in the course of this case the parties will develop a full record 
addressing issues raised that are relevant to the Commission’s decision , including the following:  
 
A. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, 
including in relation to cost or risk?  
 
B. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from 
the proposed transaction?  
 
C. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest?  
 
D. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the proposed 
transaction consistent with the public interest?  
 
E. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory 
Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other state, federal or 
foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed 
transactio n? 
 
F. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non -union workforce  
and do the protections included in the acquisition adequately protect that workforce?  
 
G. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power's ability to comply with the  
carbon -free standard  under Minn. Stat. § 216B.1691 , including any modifications of 
plans associated with the Nemadji Trail Energy Center  (a proposed 525 -megawatt  
natural gas combined -cycle power plant to be built in Superior, Wisconsin) ? 
VI. Procedural Outline   
A. Administrative Law Judge  
The Administrative Law Judge assigned to this case is  Megan McKenzie . Her address is as 
follows: Office of Administrative Hearings, 600 North Robert Street, St. Paul, Minnesota 55101. 
Her mailing address is P.O. Box 64620, St. Paul, Minnesota 55164 -0620. She can be reached 
through h er legal assistant, Nichole Sletten , at 651 .361.7857 . 
 
9 
 B. Hearing Procedure  
 •  Controlling Statutes and Rules  
 
Hearings in this matter will be conducted in accordance with the Minnesota Administrative 
Procedure Act, Minn. Stat. §§ 14.57 to 14.62; the rules of the Office of Administrative Hearings, 
Minn. R. 1400.5100 to 1400.8400; and, to the extent that they are no t superseded by those rules, 
the Commission’s Rules of Practice and Procedure, Minn. R. 7829.0100 –7829.4000.  
 
These rules and statutes can be accessed free of charge through the State of Minnesota’s website 
at www.revisor.mn.gov/pubs. Hardbound books of Minnesota’s statutes or rules may be 
requested from the Office of the Revisor of Statutes at 651 -645-1224, ext. 107, or 
https://www.mngovpublications.com/home.asp. The Office of Administrative Hearings conducts 
contested case proceedings in accordance with the Minnesota Rules of Professional Conduct and 
the Professionalism Aspirations adopted by the Minnesota State Bar Association.  
 
 • Right to Counsel and to Present Evidence  
 
In these proceedings, parties may be represented by counsel, may appear on their own behalf, or 
may be represented by another person of their choice, unless otherwise prohibited as the 
unauthorized practice of law. They have the right to present evidence, conduct cross -
examination, and make written and oral argument.3 
 
Parties should bring to the hearing all documents, records, and witnesses necessary to support 
their positions.  
 
• Discovery and Informal Disposition  
 
Any questions regarding discovery under Minn. R. 1400.6700 to 1400.6800 or informal 
disposition under Minn. R. 1400.5900 should be directed to Robert Manning, 651.201.2197, 
Minnesota Public Utilities Commission, 121 7th Place East, Suite 350, St. Paul, Minnesota, 
55101 -2147.  
 
• Protecting Not -Public Data  
 
State agencies are required by law to keep some data not public. Parties must advise the 
Administrative Law Judge if not -public data is offered into the record. They should take note that 
any not -public data admitted into evidence may become public unless a party objects and 
requests relief under Minn. Stat. § 14.60, subd. 2.  
 
 
 
 
 
3 Minn. R. 1400.2210 , 1400.5800, 1400.7100 , 1400.7800 . 
 
10 
 • Accommodations for Disabilities; Interpreter Services  
 
At the request of any individual, this agency will make accommodations to ensure that the hearing 
in this case is accessible. The agency will appoint a qualified neutral interpreter if necessary. 
Persons must promptly notify the Administrative Law Judge if  an interpreter is needed.  
 
• Scheduling Issues  
 
The times, dates, and places of evidentiary hearings in this matter will be set by order of the 
Administrative Law Judge after consultation with the Commission and  parties.  
 
• Notice of Appearance  
 
Any party intending to appear at the hearing must file a notice of appearance (Attachment A) with 
the Administrative Law Judge within 20 days of the date of this Notice and Order for Hearing.  
 
• Sanctions for Non -compliance  
 
Failure to appear at a prehearing conference, a settlement conference, or the hearing, or failure to 
comply with any order of the Administrative Law Judge, may result in facts or issues being 
resolved against the party who fails to appear or comply.  
C. Parties and Intervention  
As the petitioner, Minnesota Power is a party to these proceedings, and t he Department and the 
OAG become parties to a Commission proceeding upon filing comments.4 In addition, the 
Commission has received petitions to intervene in this matter from CUB, CURE , ECC, IBEW,  
LIUNA,  and LPI, and no one has raised an objection. In the absence of an objection, petitions for 
intervention are deemed granted 15 days after they are filed,5 and the Commission has authority 
to grant interventions otherwise.6 The Commission finds that all these outstanding petitions for 
intervention have been deemed granted by law or are otherwise meritorious.  Consequently, the 
current parties in this docket are CUB, CURE, the Department, ECC, IBEW, LIUNA, LPI , 
Minnesota Power, and OAG.  
 
Other persons or entities wishing to become formal parties should  promptly file petitions to 
intervene with the A dministrative Law Judge.7 
 
 
 
 
4 Minn. R. 7829.0800 , subp. 3.  
5 Minn. R. 7829.0800, subp. 5. 
6 Minn. R. 7829.0800, subp. 2. 
7 Minn. R. 1400.6200.  
 
11 
 VII. Prehearing Conference  
 
A prehearing conference will be held on October 21, 2024 , at 10:00  a.m., Parties may call 
+1.651.395.7448 and enter the following phone conference ID: 846 630 273# . Parties may also 
petition the Administrative Law Judge to use an alternative location on a case -by-case basis after 
the hearing notice is filed.  
 
Persons participating in the prehearing conference should be prepared to discuss time frames,  
scheduling, discovery procedures, and similar issues. Potential parties are invited to attend the  
prehearing conference and to file their petitions to intervene as soon as possible.  
 
VIII.  Applications of Ethics in Government Act  
 
The lobbying provisions of the Ethics in Government Act, Minn. Stat. § 10A.01 et seq ., may 
apply to this case. Persons appearing in this proceeding may be subject to registration, reporting, 
and other requirements set forth in that act. All persons appearing in this case are urged to refer 
to the Ethics in Government Act and to contact th e Campaign Finance and Public Disclosure 
Board with any questions at 651.539.1190.  
 
IX.  Ex Parte  Communications  
 
Restrictions on ex parte  communications with Commissioners and reporting requirements 
regarding such communications with Commission staff apply to this proceeding from the date of 
this order. Those restrictions and reporting requirements are set forth at Minn. R. 7845.7100 - 
7845. 7400, which all parties are urged to consult.  
 
 
ORDER  
 
1. Minnesota Power must supplement its petition in this proceeding by October 8, 2024, to 
include the following required information:  
 
A. A detailed explanation of whether the pending acquisition of certain interests in 
Global Infrastructure Partners  by BlackRock , Inc.,  requires Commission 
authorization under Minn. Stat. § 216B.50, and if not, why not . 
 
B. All additional information required to comply with the filing requirements under 
Minn. Stat. § 216B.50 and Minn. R. 7825.1700 and 7825.1800 with respect to the 
pending acquisition of certain interests in GIP by BlackRock .  
 
C. A discussion of affiliated interest issues that may arise between ALLETE  and 
companies held directly or indirectly in the portfolios of Canada Pension Plan 
Investment Board or BlackRock.  
 
  
 
12 
 2. The Commission requests that the Commissioner of the Minnesota Department of 
Commerce seek authority from the Commissioner of Department of Management and 
Budget to incur costs for specialized technical professional investigative services  for this 
matter pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.62, subd. 8.  
 
3. The Commission r efers this matter to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a 
contested case proceeding and asks the assigned  Administrative Law Judge  to develop  
the following issues on the record:  
 
A. Are there any potential harms to the public interest from the proposed transaction, 
including in relation to cost or risk?  
 
B. Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest 
from the proposed transaction?  
 
C. Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest?  
 
D. Are there regulatory requirements or commitments necessary to render the 
proposed transaction consistent with the public interest?  
 
E. How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin, and/or other 
state, federal or foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s 
consideration of the proposed transactio n? 
 
F. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non -union 
workforce  and do the protections included in the acquisition  agreement  
adequately protect that workforce?  
 
G. How will the acquisition impact Minnesota Power's ability to comply with the  
carbon -free standard  under § 216B.1691 , including any modifications of plans 
associated with the Nemadji Trail Energy Center?  
 
4. The Commission requests that the Administrative Law Judge issue a report and 
recommendation on these matters  no later than July 15, 2025, or earlier in the event of a 
settlement . 
  
5. The motions to intervene filed by Citizens Utility Board of Minnesota, CURE, Energy 
Cents Coalition, Large Power Intervenors, International Brotherhood of Electrical 
Workers Local No. 31, and Laborers’ International Union of North America —Minnesota 
& North Dakota are granted pursuant to Minn. R. 7829.0800, subp. 5, or otherwise.  
 
  
 
13 
 6. This o rder takes effect  immediately.  
 
 BY ORDER OF THE COMMISSION  
 
 
 
 
 Will Seuffert

STATE OF MINNESOTAOFFICE OF ADMINISTRATIVE HEARINGSFOR THE PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONIn the Matter of the Petition ofMinnesota Power for the Acquisitionof ALLETE by Canada Pension PlanInvestment Board and GlobalInfrastructure PartnersVIA ELECTRONIC FILINGMPUC DOCKET NO.E015/PA-24-198PETITION TO INTERVENE BY IBEW LOCAL UNION 31Pursuant to Minn. R. 7829.0800, and other provisions of the Minnesota Rules, InternationalBrotherhood of Electrical Workers, Local Union 31 (“Local 31”) respectfully submits itsPetition to Intervene in the above referenced docket. In support of its position, Local 31states:PETITION TO INTERVENEA. Description of Local 31Local 31 is headquartered at 2002 London Road, Suite 105, Duluth, Minnesota55812. Local 31 represents approximately 438 Minnesota Power workers, and a total ofapproximately 500 members employed by various companies owned by MinnesotaPower’s parent company, ALLETE. Local 31’s workers are employed in all facets ofMinnesota Power’s operations from generation to transmission and delivery. Local 31 hasbargained on behalf of workers with Minnesota Power/ALLETE and its predecessorMinnesota Power & Light since 1937. 2B. Local 31’s InterestsAs the certified representatives of the bargaining unit employees of MinnesotaPower and ALLETE companies, Local 31 has a direct interest in the outcome of thisproceeding that cannot be adequately represented by any other party.Local 31 represents some 438 employees of Minnesota Power. This proposedmerger has a direct bearing on the conditions of work, wages, pension benefits, healthand welfare benefits, stock plans, and collective bargaining rights of our members andthereby, also their families. As the certified representative of Minnesota Poweremployees, Local 31 has a vested interest that the outcome of the acquisition of ALLETEby Canadian Pension Plan and Global Infrastructures Partners does not negatively impactthe interests of past, current, and future bargaining unit employees.In addition to being employees of Minnesota Power, these workers are, in amajority or instances, consumers as well. As the certified representatives of thebargaining unit employees of Minnesota Power and a substantial number of additionalmembers who work and reside in Minnesota Power’s service territory, Local 31 has adirect interest in the outcome of this proceeding that cannot be adequately represented byany other party.CONCLUSIONLocal 31 is well-positioned to present issues and develop facts that assist theCommission in fully understanding the labor issues relevant to this proceeding. For theforegoing reasons, Local 31 respectfully requests that the Commission grant its petition 3to intervene in this proceeding as a party with all rights and privileges appropriate to thatstatus.Dated: September 18, 2024 Respectfully submitted,Kristin Renskers/s/ Kristin RenskersKristin RenskersBusiness RepresentativeIBEW Local 312002 London Rd, Ste 105Duluth, MN 55812PHONE: 218.969.2201EMAIL: krenskers@ibew31.com 4CERTIFICATE OF SERVICEIn the Matter of Application of MPUC DOCKET NO. International Brotherhood of Electrical WorkersLocal Union No. 312002 London Road Suite 105 Duluth MN 55812(218) 728-4248 Fax (218) 728-1651 E-Mail:ibew31@ibew31.com www.ibew31.comSeptember 18, 2024VIA E-FILINGWill SeuffertExecutive SecretaryMinnesota Public Utilities Commission121 7th Place East, Suite 350St. Paul, MN 55101-2147Re: In the Matter the Petition of Minnesota Power for the Acquisition of ALLETE by CanadaPension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure PartnersDocket No. E015/PA-24-198Dear Mr. Seuffert,We, the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local Union 31 (“Local 31”),respectfully submit our comments in response to the PUC’s September 19, 2024 briefing papersand decision options regarding Minnesota Power’s (“the Company”) Petition for the Acquisitionof ALLETE by Canada Pension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners (“thepartners).We feel that the questions posed by the PUC will adequately allow us to respond to ourinterests in the Acquisition. We plan to provide testimony regarding option 8 (G): How willthe Acquisition impact Minnesota Power’s union and non-union workforce and do theprotections included in the Acquisition adequately protect that workforce?We continue to examine the possible impacts on the workforce and will raise thoseissues in the proceeding. The Acquisition brings with it opportunity to examine therelationship between IBEW Local 31 and the Company in its new form. Question 8(G) is broadenough to cover our intended scope, and we appreciate the opportunity to develop the record asit pertains to workforce. Local 31 supports option 10.: Establish a deadline of June 15, 2025, for the ALJ Report.We prefer to work through our concerns with the Company in a timely manner tominimize the protracted uncertainty a longer timeline may bring. We see no advantage orgreater outcome in lengthening the Company’s preferred and reasonable timeline. If anything,we prefer the Company and partners continue to address our concerns or ideas in real time tomeet the timelines they have set forth. Drawing out the process may have a negative impact onemployee hiring, retention, morale. Local 31 prefers to work in the given timeline towardmutually agreeable ends.Dated: September 18, 2024 Respectfully submitted,Kristin Renskers/s/ Kristin RenskersKristin RenskersBusiness RepresentativeIBEW Local 312002 London Rd, Ste 105Duluth, MN 55812PHONE: 218.969.2201EMAIL: krenskers@ibew31.com CERTIFICATE OF SERVICEIn the Matter of Application of MPUC DOCKET NO. MINNESOTA PUBLIC UTILITIES COMMISSIONIn the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota Power for Acquisition of ALLETE by CanadaPension Plan Investment Board and Global Infrastructure Partners(Docket No. E-015/PA-24-198)Laborers District Council of Minnesota and North Dakota Petition for InterventionThe Laborers District Council of Minnesota and North Dakota (“LIUNA”) hereby petitions forintervention as a party in Minnesota Public Utility Commission (“Commission”) consideration ofthe petition of Minnesota Power (“MP”) concerning the proposed acquisition of MP parentcompany ALLETE by the Canadian Pension Plan Investment Board and Global InfrastructurePartners.LIUNA is a democratic labor organization that, together with its five affiliated Local Unions,represents more than 28,000 construction workers, public employees, and their familymembers in Minnesota and North Dakota. LIUNA’s principal place of business is located at 81East Little Canada Road in Little Canada, Minnesota. LIUNA is affiliated with the Laborers’International Union of North America, which represents roughly half a million constructionworkers and public employees across the United States and Canada.LIUNA and its affiliated Local Unions represent members in many capacities, including, but notlimited to, referring members for construction employment; bargaining with union employersover wages, benefits and working conditions; representing members in disputes withemployers; encouraging construction owners and contractors to use union labor; advocating forpublic policies that protect the rights and livelihood of workers; providing health, retirement,training, and vacation savings benefits through joint labor-management funds; and educatingour members about issues that affect their jobs and lives.LIUNA’s legal rights, duties, or privileges will be affected by the disposition of this docket. LIUNArepresents more than 1,000 members who live in Northern Minnesota and rely on MP forelectric service, either directly or through one of the utility’s wholesale electric customers,along with hundreds of additional members served by Northern Minnesota cooperative utilitiesthat use MP generation and transmission resources to support their own ability to deliverreliable electric service to their customers. These members will be impacted by theCommission’s decision to approve or deny the proposed acquisition.LIUNA also represents hundreds of members who earn their living building and maintainingcoal- and gas-fired thermal power plants, hydroelectric dams, wind farms, and solar installationsthat provide power to MP customers. These members will be directly and indirectly affected by1the Commission’s decision in this matter which could affect the utility’s access to capital andstrategy with respect to asset maintenance and new investment.Finally, LIUNA represents hundreds of members in Northern Minnesota who earn a livingbuilding and maintaining industrial and commercial facilities served by MP, including miningoperations that provide the largest single source of both construction employment and electricload in MP service territory. These members will also be impacted by the Commission’s decisionin this matter which could affect the reliability and affordability of commercial and industrialelectric service.LIUNA seeks full party status in the above-captioned docket to protect the rights and welfare ofour members, families and communities, and to ensure that the Commission’s ultimate decisionis consistent with the interest of members and the public based on the unique perspective ofmen and women who build and maintain our energy system and critical infrastructure. No otherparty to the proceedings can adequately represent the interests of our union and our members,or provide our unique insights on the proposed project as set forth aboveLIUNA Minnesota has reviewed the requirements of Minn. R. 1400.7100 and has extensiveexperience as a formal party and informal participant in dozens of Commission proceedings. Weare prepared to meet our obligations as a party to these cases going forward as the Commissionand Office of Administrative Hearings instructs.Dated: September 18, 2024 Respectfully Submitted,By: Kevin Pranis, Marketing ManagerLIUNA Minnesota & North Dakota81 East Little Canada RoadSt. Paul, MN 55117

SECTION 5 - CORPORATE GOVERNANCE AND MANAGEMENT
Item 5.07    Submission of Matters to a Vote of Security Holders.
ALLETE, Inc. (the “Company”) held a special meeting of shareholders on August 21, 2024 (the “Special Meeting”). The Special Meeting was held in
order for the shareholders of the Company to vote on the following proposals set forth in the Company’s definitive proxy statement (the “Proxy
Statement”) filed by the Company with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on July 10, 2024. As of the close of business on July 1, 2024, the
record date for the Special Meeting, the Company had a total of 57,754,294 shares of common stock outstanding and entitled to vote at the Special
Meeting, of which 43,949,189 shares, representing approximately 76 percent of the outstanding shares of common stock, were represented at the Special
Meeting in person or by proxy. Each matter voted upon at the Special Meeting and the final results of the voting on each such matter are presented below.
For a complete description of the matters voted upon at the Special Meeting, see the Proxy Statement. There were no recorded broker non-votes.
Item 1 - Merger Proposal.
The Company’s shareholders approved and adopted the Agreement and Plan of Merger, dated as of May 5, 2024, by and among the Company, Alloy Parent
LLC (“Parent”) and Alloy Merger Sub LLC, a wholly owned subsidiary of Parent (“Merger Sub”), and approved the transactions contemplated thereby,
including the merger (the “Merger”) of Merger Sub with and into the Company (the “Merger Proposal”), by the following vote:
Votes For Votes Against Abstentions
42,640,213 1,171,399 137,577
Item 2 - Merger-Related Compensation Proposal.
The Company’s shareholders approved, on a nonbinding, advisory basis, the compensation that will or may become payable by the Company to its named
executive officers in connection with the Merger, by the following vote:
Votes For Votes Against Abstentions
39,520,180 4,109,938 319,071
Item 3 - Special Meeting Adjournment Proposal.
In connection with the Special Meeting, the Company also solicited proxies with respect to a proposal which would have given the Company’s board of
directors authority to adjourn the Special Meeting, if such proposal was called at the Special Meeting, including to solicit additional proxies in favor of the
Merger Proposal if there were insufficient votes at the time of the Special Meeting to approve the Merger Proposal or in the absence of a quorum (the
“Special Meeting Adjournment Proposal”). As a quorum was present and there were sufficient votes at the time of the Special Meeting to approve the
Merger Proposal, the Special Meeting Adjournment Proposal was unnecessary and such proposal was not submitted to shareholders for approval at the
Special Meeting.
SECTION 7 – REGULATION FD
Item 7.01. Regulation FD Disclosure
On August 21, 2024, the Company issued a press release announcing the results of the shareholder vote at the Special Meeting. The press release is
attached to this report as Exhibit 99.1 and is incorporated herein by reference.
The press release is being furnished, not filed, pursuant to Regulation FD. Accordingly, the press release will not be incorporated by reference into any
registration statement filed by the Company under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the “Securities Act”), unless specifically identified therein as
being incorporated therein by reference. The furnishing of the press release is not intended to, and does not, constitute a determination or admission by the
Company that the information in the press release is material or complete, or that investors should consider this information before making an investment
decision with respect to any security of the Company or any of its affiliates.

In the Matter of the Petition of Minnesota

and Global Infrastructure Partners  PUC Docket No. E015/PA -24-198  
 
PETITION TO INTERVENE  
 
I. INTRODUCTION  
On July 19, 2024, Minnesota Power (“MP , ” “the Company”) ﬁled its initial petition in the 
above -referenced matter. Pursuant to Minn. R. 7829.0800, the Energy CENTS Coalition 
(“ECC”) hereby petitions to intervene in this proceeding with all rights of a party.  
II. IDENTITY OF THE PETITIONER  
ECC is a 501(c)3 nonproﬁt advocate and service provider that works to ensure that low - 
and ﬁxed-income utility customers have access to affordable energy. For over 30 years, 
ECC has advocated before the Commission and State Legislature, not just on behal f of 
consumers broadly but speciﬁcally for low -income consumers. ECC also serves as a 
third -party administrator for Xcel Energy’s low-income affordability and conservation 
programs , providing us direct insight into the practical realities of administering  
affordabilit y programming .  
III. ANALYSIS  
Minn. R. 7829.0800 states th e following  regarding petitions to intervene :  
The petition must allege the grounds for intervention and must be granted upon a 
showing that …the outcome of the proceeding will bind or affect the person with 
respect to an interest peculiar to that person, as distinguished from an interest common to the public or other ratepayers in general, or the person's interests are 
not adequately represente d by one or more other parties participating in the case.
1 
ECC’s charge is to advocate on behalf of low -income energy consumers across the 
state . Our ability to do so, in recent years, has been aided by the candor and 
 
1 Minn. R. 1 7829.0800, subp. 2  
accessibility of MP leadership in negotiations over affordability programming and 
energy policy.2 A potential change in ownership has signiﬁcant  implications for that 
relationship going forward.  
The historical dividends of ECC’s  partnership with MP  are concrete and profound. The 
Company’s current affordability program, CARE, is a  result of a Commission Order  in 
the Company’s 2009 rate case  to create an affordability beneﬁt  modeled on Xcel’s 
PowerON  program , which came in direct response to advocacy  by ECC.3 Throughout 
the ensuing 15 years, ECC engaged consistently with MP on ways to expand and improve the CARE program.  As ECC noted in its recent ﬁling, that engagement has 
culminated  in CARE maturing into one of the most effective affordability  programs in 
the state.
4  
As an advocate for low -income utility customers, ECC has a unique interest in the 
maintenance of low-income programming under the Company’s new ownership structure. In its initial petition in this docket, the Company pledged to maintain 
investment in and access to its current level of affordability  programs.
5 We thank MP for 
making that commitment and want to ensure that it is not undermined throughout the 
course of the proceedings.   
ECC is eminently qualiﬁed to serve th at role of safeguard of affordability programming. 
We are unique among consumer advocates in that our advocacy is complemented with our practical experience as  a third-party administrator for the affordability programs of 
another utility, Xcel Energy. Any consideration of adequacy of representation ought to 
consider those unique competencies  and the value we bring in developing the record in 
this matter . 
IV. CONCLUSION  
As an advocate for low -income utility customers  with a deep partnership with the 
Company , ECC has a profound stake in the results of this proceeding.  We respectfully 
request the right to intervene as a party, to ensure that the interests of low-income 
customers are adequately represented.
