 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
 BACKGROUND  
 
On May 5, 2024, ALLETE, Inc., Minnesota Power ’s parent company , entered into a merger 
agreement with Canada Pension Plan Investment Board (“CPP Investments”) and Global 
Infrastructure Partners (“GIP”). Under this agreement, a new partner -created entity known as 
“Alloy Parent LLC” (“Parent”) will acquire all shares of  ALLETE and hold all interest in ALLETE 
going forward (“Acquisition”). Acquisition terms are set forth in an Agreement and Plan of 
Merger dated May 5, 2024 (“Merger Agreement”), provided by Minn esota Power as 
Attachment B of its petition.  
 
On July 19, 2024 Minnesota Power (“the Company”) filed a petition (Petition) seeking approval 
for Allete  to be acquired  by entities controlled and managed by CPP and GIP. Allete’s 
outstanding common equity would be acquired for $67/share  which, post -transaction, will 
result in GIP owning sixty percent (60%) of Allete and CPP owning forty percent (40%).  
 
The statute and rules are provided below for reference.  
 
Statute:  
216B.50 RESTRICTIONS ON PROPERTY TRANSFER AND MERGER.  
Subdivision 1. Commission approval required.  
 No public utility shall sell, acquire, lease, or rent any plant as an operating unit or system in this 
state for a total consideration in excess of $1,000,000, or merge or consolidate with another 
public utility or transmission company operating in this st ate, without first being authorized so 
to do by the commission. Upon the filing of an application for the approval and consent of the 
commission, the commission shall investigate, with or without public hearing. The commission 
shall hold a public hearing,  upon such notice as the commission may require.  If the commission 
finds that the proposed action is consistent with the public interest, it shall give its consent 
and approval by order in writing. In reaching its determination, the commission shall take 
into consideration the reasonable value of the pro perty, plant, or securities to be acquired or 
disposed of, or merged and consolidated.  
This section does not apply to the purchase of property to replace or add to the plant of the 
public utility by construction.  
Rules:  
7825.1700 PROCEDURE FOR APPROVAL TO ACQUIRE PROPERTY.  
A public utility, prior to entering into a transaction, shall petition for and receive from the 
commission by formal written order approval for such transaction. A petition for approval of 
capital structure (parts 7825.1000 to 7825.1500) shall be filed con currently with the petition for 
P a g e | 2 
 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
 approval of transfer, merger, or consolidation if consideration for such a transaction is a 
security or securities as defined in part 7825.1000. The commission may require an 
independent valuation of the property involved in the transaction.  
7825.1800 FILING REQUIREMENTS FOR PETITIONS TO ACQUIRE PROPERTY.  Petitions for 
approval to acquire property shall contain one original and three copies of the following 
information, either in the petition or as exhibits attached thereto:  
A. Petitions for approval of a merger or of a consolidation shall be accompanied by the 
following: the petition signed by all parties; all information, for each public utility, as required in 
parts 7825.1400 and 7825.1500; the detailed reasons of the petit ions and each party for 
entering into the proposed transaction, and all facts warranting the same; the full terms and 
conditions of the proposed merger or consolidation.  
B. Petitions for approval of a transfer of property shall be accompanied by the followin g: all 
information as required in part 7825.1400, items A to J; the agreed upon purchase price and 
the terms for payment and other considerations.  
C. A description of the property involved in the transaction including any franchises, permits, or 
operative rights, and the original cost of such property, individually or by class, the depreciation 
and amortization reserves applicable to such property, i ndividually or by class. If the original 
cost is unknown, an estimate shall be made of such cost. A detailed description of the method 
and all supporting documents used in such estimate shall be submitted.  
D. Other pertinent facts or additional information that the commission may require.  
DISCUSSION  
I. ALLETE ’s Petition  
A. Introduction of Parties  
1. CPP Investments  
CPP Investments is a professional management organization that manages the Canada Pension 
Plan Fund, representing funds not needed by the Canada Pension Plan (“CPP”) to pay benefits 
in the best interests of CPP’s more than 22 million participating contribu tors and beneficiaries 
across Canada. CPP Investments is governed and managed independently of CPP and at arm’s 
length from governments. As of March 31, 2024, a ssets under management total C$632.3 
billion , including C$267.6 billion (US$197.7 billion) inves ted direct ly or indirectly in the United 
States, in equity and fixed income in public and private companies.   
 
CPP is an institutional investor with holdings  across the energy sector, focusing on the energy 
transition. CPP considers sustainability -related factors and has committed to achieve net -zero 
emissions across all scopes by 2050, in both portfolio and operations, and growing its Green & 
P a g e | 3 
 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
 Transition assets by C$130 billion by 2030.  
 
The Petition cited CPP ’s partnership with Puget Sound Energy, the largest electric and gas utility 
in Washington state with 1.2 million customers, as an example of CPP Investments ’ deep 
expertise with utilities. Minnesota Power stated that t his partnership allowed Puget to execute 
its long -term growth strategy and accelerate its decarbonization efforts.1 
 
The Petition  stated  the Acquisition aligned with CPP Investments’ long -term investment 
strategy, which includes investment in both conventional and renewable energy assets globally 
and will bring sector expertise and long -term capital to support ALLETE’s strong management 
team.   
2. Global Infrastructure Partners  
GIP is the trading name for Global Infrastructure Management, LLC. GIP has approximately $115 
billion in assets under management and specializes in investing, owning, and/or operating large 
and complex assets across the energy, transport ation , digital infrastructure, and water and 
waste management sectors. GIP  companies in its portfolio  employ  over 116,000 people . GIP 
aspires to be one of the world’s leading owners, developers, and operators of renewable 
energy assets.  
 
The Petition noted that it is GIP’s practice to invest in infrastructure assets using common 
investment funds or similar investment structures that include three separate legal entities – a 
general partner with legal authority and control over the actions and management of the fund, 
a limited partner(s) which invest s in the fund but do not participate in day -to-day decisions of 
the fund, and the fund itself.  The Petition argued that t his type of structure allows GIP to 
provide clear lines of ownership and control of the assets in which each fund invests.  
 
Earlier this year , GIP announced  that it will be acquired by BlackRock. After the acquisition, 
BlackRock will have an indirect interest in the ultimate general partner entities that control 
each GIP fund, but GIP will continue to be the fund manager. The Petition asserted that GIP’s 
strategic and day -to-day operations and activities, including the funds that are investing in 
ALLETE, will continue to be managed as they are now and the current GIP management team 
will continue to manage its operations . This t ransaction is anticipated to close third quarter 
2024.   
3. The Acquisition  
The terms and conditions of the acquisition are described in a Merger Agreement, provided as 
Attachment B of the Petition. The SEC Proxy Statement, with further details, is also available as 
Attachment L.  
 
 
1 Petition of Minnesota Power, p. 7  
P a g e | 4 
 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
  
Figure 1: Post -Acquisition Organizational Structure  
 
 
Under the Merger Agreement, CPP Investments will acquire , through Parent,  40% of the 
outstanding common stock of ALLETE. GIP will control its 60% ownership of Parent through two 
funds: Global Infrastructure Partners V (GIP Fund V) and Tower Bridge Infrastructure Partners, 
L.P. (Tower Bridge), both managed by GIP -controlled affiliates. Parent has created a subsidiary, 
known as Alloy M erger Sub LLC (Merger Sub) for the purpose of merging with ALLETE. At 
closing, ALLETE will merge into Merger Sub, with ALLETE as the surviving entity. Current ALLETE 
shareholders will receive $67.00 per share in cash.  
 
Although a small portion of ALLETE and Minnesota Power ’s debt  will be refinanced  with no cost 
effect to the regulated utility , no additional debt in connection with the acquisition  will be 
incurred . The overall transaction value is approximately $6.2 billion : $3.9 billion i n ALLETE 
shares and $2.3 billion in Allete debt assumption . After these transactions, ALLETE will be a 
Parent wholly owned subsidiary. A new tax -sharing agreement between Parent, ALLETE, and 
Minnesota Power will be brought before the Comm ission after consummation of the 
agreement, which will be the only change to the affiliated interest relationships between 
ALLETE entities as a result of the Acquisition. ALLETE will remain a standalone company and will 
have the same relationship with Minnesota Power and the Commission as now.  MP stated that 
ALLETE will continue to have its own Board of Directors with fiduciary obligations and oversight 
responsibilities  with the same components as constituted now . 
B. Purpose and Benefits of Acquisition  
1. Standard of Review  
Minnesota Power ’s Petition  stated that Minnesota Law require s that the Commission find that 

P a g e | 5 
 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
 the Acquisition is “consistent with the public interest”.2 Minnesota Power argued that , in prior 
cases , the Commission has found that this standard does not require an affirmative finding of 
public benefit. Instead, it only requires that the merger is compatible with the public interest.3 
This means that the Acquisition “cannot contravene the public interest…and must be shown to 
be compatible with it.”4 
2. Application of Standard  
Minnesota Power argued that the Acquisition is consistent with the public interest and readily 
meets the standard. There will be no adverse impact to customers, service cost or quality, 
employees, or communities, according to Minnesota Power. The Partners are not seeking to 
make changes to the operation of the Minnesota Power utility or the regulatory construct in 
Minnesota. Minnesota Power argued that this transaction is not about cutting costs or 
fundamentally changing cost structures or long -term  plans f or the Minnesota Power utility and 
it is instead about finding a better way to support the Company’s ongoing sustainability efforts 
and achievement of State policy goals.  
 
Minnesota Power argued that, in fact, the Acquisition will produce benefits by allowing ALLETE 
to partner with global leaders in the infrastructure space who intend to provide the Company 
with the capital necessary in transitioning to cleaner energy while maintaining reliable, safe, 
and affordable service.  
 
Minnesota Power also noted that the acquisition will not change Commission regulatory 
authority. Minnesota Power asserted that it applied rigorous due diligence in evaluating this 
acquisition and has acquired partners that share its vision, commitment to clean energy, and 
support for its customers, communities, and quality of service. Minnesota Power noted that, in 
addition to MPUC approval, Public Service Commission of Wisconsin (PSCW) and Federal Energy 
Regulatory Commission  (FERC ) approvals are being sou ght. MP agreed to notify the Commission 
regarding the outcome of th ose proceedings via filings through eDockets.  
 
Minnesota Power noted that, as a share of market capitalization, ALLETE is , as of March 2024,  
the largest investor in renewable energy of all publicly traded utilities in the US.5 Since future 
substantial investments will be needed in concert with Minnesota’s decarbonization efforts , 
partnering with highly experienced owners who share its values and can dedicate resources to

II. Comments  
A. Department of Commerce  
The Department of Commerce filed Comments on the question of completeness of the 
application, especially regarding the nexus of the acquisition of ALLETE by GIP and CPP 
Investments with the acquisition of GIP by BlackRock. The Department also filed comments on 
the question of referral for a contested case and issues requiring record development and other 
issues or concerns.  
1. Completeness of the Application  
The Department noted that the sale of GIP to BlackRock was likely but not certain to be 
complete by the time the acquisition of ALLETE by GIP was finalized. The Department found 
that the Petition was complete as to GIP and CPP, but it did not have complete  information on 
BlackRock. The Department presented t wo scenarios  where the application is incomplete or 
where a further petition would be required : 
 
SCENARIO A:   The BlackRock acquisition of GIP is completed before the GIP acquisition of 
ALLETE.  
 
In this situation, “BlackRock will have an indirect controlling interest in GI P’s public utility 
subsidiaries”6, meaning that, for the purposes of Commission authorization of the Acquisition, it 
is BlackRock, not GIP, who will be the ultimate controlling owner of 60% - a majority interest - 
of ALLETE. The Petition provides significant information on GIP, but very l ittle about BlackRock. 
As such, the Petition is incomplete.  
 
SCENARIO B:   The BlackRock acquisition of GIP is not completed before the GIP acquisition of 
ALLETE is closed.  
 
In this situation, GIP will become a public utility, and the GIP/BlackRock Transaction becomes 
an acquisition requiring Commission authorization under Minn. Stat.  §216B.50 in a separate 
proceeding. In this situation, this petition is complete, but Minnesota Power will need to file a 
separate petition containing complete information on BlackRock.

2. Referral to OAH  
The Department recommended referral to OAH. Aspects of this acquisition are novel and highly 
technical issues of fact and policy, and the Department anticipated a significant amount of 
discovery, fact -finding, and record development best facilitated by a c ontested case 
proceeding.  
 
The Department also recommended an ALJ report deadline of June 15, 2025. Though there is 
no statutory deadline for this proceeding, the Department believes that this date best balances 
the Company’s indicated preference for a mid -2025 closing with need for  adequate time for 
parties to develop a full and robust record for this complex transaction.  
3. Issues Requiring Record Development  
The Department ’s review of the Acquisition is in early stages, and so the Department 
recommended requiring a broad definition of issues for record development. At minimum, the 
Department recommended the following issues for development:  
 
• Are there any harms, costs, or risks to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from 
the proposed transaction?  
• Are there any potential benefits to ratepayers, Minnesota, or the public interest from 
the proposed transaction?  
• Considering all relevant factors and applicable law, is the proposed transaction 
consistent with the public interest?  
• Are there regulatory requirements or commitments that could mitigate the harms,

 costs, or risks of the proposed transaction enough to render it consistent with the public 
interest?  
• How do relevant and related dockets pending before the Federal Energy Regulatory 
Commission, Wisconsin Public Service Commission, and/or other state, federal or 
foreign government agencies impact the Commission’s consideration of the proposed 
transaction?  
4. Additional Issues or Concerns  
a. Affiliated Interest  
The Department raised issues regarding ALLETE’s definition of “affiliated interest” as proposed 
in its acquisition agreement. In the Petition, MP addressed affiliated interests from the 
perspectives of:  
 
• the impact of the Acquisition on existing affiliate d interest  contracts and arrangements 
within the ALLETE family of companies;  
• whether the Merger Agreement itself is an affiliated interest agreement; and  
• whether any unaffiliated interests with which ALLETE currently has existing contracts  
may become affiliated interests as a result of the Acquisition.  
 
The Department noted that MP specifically did not include CPP or its affiliates , operating or 
portfolio companies, investment funds or vehicles, or investee companies. If CPP owns, directly 
or indirectly, five percent or more of these entities, t he Department does not believe that it is 
clear that these entities are not covered by the affiliated  interest statute.  
 
Similarly, BlackRock’s multi -trillion dollar investment portfolios include thousands of companies 
which BlackRock directly or indirectly owns 5% or more. The Department ’s understanding is 
that all of these companies would become affiliates of ALLETE and any contract or agreement 
ALLETE or Minnesota Power has, now or in the future, would become an affiliated interest 
agreement requiring Commission approval.  
 
The Department recommended that this issue be further developed in the record in this 
docket, and that Minnesota Power be required to supplement its Petition by November 1, 
2024 , with a filing that comprehensively addresses the potential affiliate status of the portfolio 
holdings of the Partners (CPP and GIP) and BlackRock.  
b. Request for Specialized Technical Professional Investigative Services  
The Department noted that aspects of the proposed acquisition, including complex legal 
structures and the nature of the acquiring entities, raise novel and highly technical issues of fact 
and policy. The Department requested that the Commission determine t hat it is necessary for 
the Department to obtain specialized technical professional investigative services to the 
Department in its review, pursuant to Minn. Stat. § 216B.62, subd. 8 (2023).

 B.  Office of the Attorney General  
The Office of the Attorney General (OA G) recommended that the Petition be referred to the 
Office of Administrative Hearing s to help determine whether the proposed transaction is in the 
public interest. OA G had several questions as to whether the proposed transaction would harm 
ratepayers and the public interests and whether any benefits would offset those harms.  OAG 
enumerated several specific questions.  
1. It is unclear whether the proposed transaction is consistent with 
the public interest . 
OAG argued that potential benefits and harms have not yet been developed. OA G identified 
several types of harms the Commission has cited in past cases, including transaction costs, 
service -quality impairment, loss of regulatory oversight, reduced competition, acquirer’s debt, 
cross -subsidization/self -dealing, ratepayer underwriting  of acquisition adjustments/goodwill, 
and increased complexity of ensuring ratepayer protection. OA G noted that offsetting benefits 
to ratepayers have not yet been clarified, nor is it clear that benefits outweigh risks.  
 
OAG note d that the new owner s’ goals and strategies are likely different from current 
ownership ’s. OA G argued that the fact that the buyers are willing to pay a premium suggests 
that the buyers will be expecting to recover a return on that premium, and that it is reasonable 
to expect that some of that premium would be expected to come from Minnesota Power,  
ALLETE’s largest division, and a captive ratepayer revenue source.  OAG is concerned that taking 
ALLETE private may create a loss of transparency and change the dynamics of information flow, 
and questioned whet her voluntary cooperation will be as enforceable as disclosures required of 
publicly traded companies. OA G also expressed concerns that MP will go from being the largest 
part of ALLETE to being a small part of the new company, and that the decreased relevance of 
MP may be harmful to ratepayers , Minnesota, and the public interest . 
 
2. The proposed transaction would benefit shareholders but  
appears to have few if any benefits for ratepayers.  
OAG noted that most contractual commitments maintain the status quo, they do not improve 
the situation for ratepayers. In OAG’s view, maintaining the status quo is not a ‘benefit’. At 
best, these contractual commitments mitigate risk. OA G also noted that the petition identified 
better alternatives to  the capital marketplace for financing but  did not identify or commit to 
any monetary benefit to ratepayers from these alternatives.   
 
OAG contrasted this with the 19% to 22% premium ALLETE shareholders will receive from the 
merger. OA G cited specifically that ALLETE’s CEO would receive over $2.6 million for her shares, 
and that BlackRock – one of the new owners – would increase its ownership stake from 13.5% 
to 60% while receiving a premium on its current 13.5% stake.

some mergers have included such benefits, the Commission has approved mergers with other 
benefits.10 11  
 
Minnesota Power submitted that since this standard is well established, statutory, and has 
been applied recently, there is no need to take action to address it at this time. MP noted that 
the ALJ Report will likely include a Standard of Review discussion for Commission review and 
consideration, and pros and cons of the Acquisition will be discus sed throughout the 
proceeding.  
 
4. Affiliated Interests  
Minnesota Power stated that, though the Department’s concern about BlackRock and affiliated 
interests are understandable, it would be impractical and inconsistent with the statute, prior

unlikely to have a material impact on Minnesota Power or its customers.  Further, as the 
acquisition of GIP by BlackRock has not yet cl osed, there are limitations on the information 
available to MP about investments and other matters unrelated to GIP/ALLETE.

III. Staff Analysis  
A. Referral to OAH  
Staff agrees with most parties and Minnesota Power that the issues in this docket are complex 
and warrant referral to the Office of Administrative Hearings for a contested case and 
evidentiary hearings under an Administrative Law Judge. The questions devel oped by the 
Department, Office of the Attorney General, LPI, and CUB, are a good general guide for the ALJ, 
as would be the questions provided by Minnesota Power. Staff does general ly prefer Minnesota 
Power’s version of the fourth question ( Decision Option  8-D2), as the other parties’ version 
(Decision Option 8 -D1) seems to assume that enough harms exist that ‘regulatory requirements 
or commitments’ are needed, which is a fact yet to be decided.  
 
P a g e | 20 
 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
 Staff also generally supports a schedule leading to an approximately mid -June ALJ Report date, 
believing that this would provide ALLETE plenty of time to complete the merger. Such a 
schedule would closely align with MP’s proposed (revised) timelines. However, Staff does not 
consider MP’s proposed timelines reasonable for Staff to complete its work. Procedurally, MP’s 
schedule does not include exceptions to the ALJ Report. Once exceptions are filed , Staff will 
need to file briefing papers two weeks prior to a Commission Agenda Meeting; therefore, Staff 
considers a September agenda meeting with an Order approximately one month later to be 
more realistic that it will probably need 60 days after . Since the is no statutory deadline for this 
proceeding, a decision regarding when the Commission will meet is not required at this time. 
Staff simply offers this information so that a realistic expectation level exists from the onset.  
 
The Office of the Attorney General does not state a date for the ALJ report, only stating an 
intention that the merger happen close to February 5, 2026, the absolute deadline. Given the 
time it takes to close a transaction of this size, this would require an ALJ report date of no later 
than early August, for a late October or early November Commission order date. Staff believes 
that pushing the deadline closer to February 5th does not gain enough additional benefit to 
justify the potential risk that ALLETE would need to incur interim capital costs which would be 
likely partially borne by ratepayers, to gain what would likely only be at most a few weeks of 
discovery time.  
B. Affiliate d Interests  
The question of whether companies owned by  CPP or  BlackRock , or owned by BlackRock 
investment funds (which are financed by investors and managed by BlackRock) would be an 
affiliated interest under Minnesota law is a legal question which is beyond the scope of th ese 
Briefing Paper s. However, in relation to investment banks owning utilities, Staff would like to 
address the practical concerns related to the Department’s interpretation of affiliate d interest.  
 
It is unlikely that the idea that a pension fund or investment bank managing hundreds of billions 
or trillions in assets would end up owning a Minnesota utility crossed Minnesota Legislators ’ 
minds  when they wrote the affiliated  interest statute  in 1974 .12 Staff would note  that the 
decision here may have very broad  implications, as institutional investors own greater than 5% 
of other Minnesota utilities than Minnesota Power. Though these are not controlling interests, 
they are voting shares, and consideration should be given to distinguishing companies in which 
broadly invested investment funds own minority shares of Minnesota utilities from companies 
where funds own majority interests . For example, due to Xcel Energy’s presence in the S&P 
500, Xcel’s largest owners are Vanguard (11.52%), Vanguard Index Fun ds (9.47%), SPDR 
(5.74%), and iShares (5%). At least one of these entities would own 5% of all S&P 500 
companies, rendering all contracts with S&P 500 companies “ affiliated interest” contracts for 
Xcel under the Department’s interpretation .13 
 
12 Minn Stat. §216B.48 was written in 1974 and amended in 1978 and 1993.  
13 Minn Stat §216B.48 defines “Affiliated Interests” to include “every corporation five percent or more of whose 
voting securities is owned by any person or corporation owning five percent or more of the voting securities of

 Staff Briefing Papers for Docket No. E-015/PA -24-198   
 
         
  
Further, as of May, 2024, Vanguard in total manages $9.3 trillion globally. It is unlikely that 
there are a significant number of  large or medium -sized  publicly traded companies in the 
United States that Vanguard and/or BlackRock don’t own 5% or more of  – including Minnesota 
Power, MDU Resources Group (parent of Montana -Dakota) – also 8% owned by BlackRock, 
CenterPoint Energy (12.11% Vanguard, 7.94% BlackRock), and WEC Energy (12.57% Vanguard, 
9.24% BlackRock).14 Otter Tail Corporation, which owns Otter Tail Power Co., is 15.53% owned 
by BlackRock, Inc. and 12.44% owned by Vanguard Group.   
 
Given the nature of Vanguard  (which on its own controls close to 10% of all publicly traded 
stock in the United States)  and BlackRock, it is likely that virtually every contract that many, if 
not all  our investor owned -utilities undertake with a publicly traded corporation – and with 
some privately held businesses – would be come  ‘affiliate d interest’ contracts under the 
interpretation used by the Department. This could potentially result in an increase in the 
number of contracts requiring Commission approval beyond Staff’s  – and the Department’s - 
current capacity to process in a timely manner.   
 
If this acquisition goes through, BlackRock will control 60% of Minnesota Power, via Allete and 
GIP. However, even without this sale, all of the above facts will continue to be true regarding 
Vanguard and BlackRock controlling at least 5% of Minnesota inve stor-owned utilities. If the 
Department’s interpretation of the statute is legally correct, then BlackRock, as well as 
Vanguard, already owns a large enough share of Allete (as well as Xcel, Otter Tail, MERC, and 
other Minnesota utilities), to trigger the statute.  
 
C. Additional item for record development  
Staff notes that in previous public utility acquisitions, approval conditions included a 
moratorium on rate increases over a period of time. Based on these prior decisions, the 
Commission may want to request record development regarding whether such a mora torium 
would be appropriate in this instance.

toward this 5%  for BlackRock , Vanguard both owns 5% of each Minnesota utility, and owns 5% of a large 
percentage of  publicly trade d corporations in the United States, and many internationally.

PETITION TO INTERVENE  OF CURE  
 
Pursuant to Minn esota Rul es 7829.2400, subpart 6, and 7829.0800 , CURE  hereby petitions 
to intervene  as a full party in the above -referenced docket , and the appropriate matter when it is 
referred to the Office of Administrative Hearings . CURE has long advocated for energy democracy 
in rural electric service territories, both regarding investor -owned utilities and Minnesota’s rural 
electric cooperatives. CURE has also taken part in efforts to combat fossil fuel  infrastructure 
buildout overseen by the Public Utilities Commission (Commission) . Due to these existing interests 
in rural energy democracy and clean energy development,  CURE  now wishes to join as a named 
party in these proceedings .  
CURE  is a rural, Minnesota -based nonprofit dedicated to protecting and restoring resilient 
rural landscapes and building vibrant, just, and equitable rural communities by harnessing the 
power of citizens who care about them. CURE works in the areas of climate, energy, rural 
democracy, and water, with a focus on civic engagement flowing through all projects. CURE’s  
support and constituency  is comprised of people  who care about the well -being of their neighbors, 
the health of the land and water, and the legacy we leave for future generations. For over 30 years 
2 
 CURE has maintained a base in rural  regions of the state , including staff and members in the 
Arrowhead region and Duluth,  and m any of our supporters  live and work in the communities  this 
project would impact.  
 
INTERVENTION RIGHTS  
Minn esota  Rule 7829.0800, subp. 1.  states  that “ A person who desires to become a party to 
a proceeding shall file a petition to intervene within the time set in this chapter .” A petition shall 
be granted upon a showing that “ the outcome of the proceeding will bind or affect the person with 
respect to an interest peculiar to that person, as distinguished from an interest common to the 
public or other ratepayers in general, or the person's interests are not adequately represente d by 
one or more other parties participati ng in the case .” Id. subp. 2.  
CURE participates in Commission dockets related to  development of environm entally 
harmful or helpful infrastructure in rural parts of Minnesota , as a part of its mission to protect and 
restore resilient rural landscapes and build vibrant, just, and equitable rural communities . CURE’s 
interest s in this docket are not adequately represented by other commenters/potential parties  
because CUR E’s work includes promoting rural environmental democracy while  combating the 
continuation of fossil fuel infrastructure in Minnesota and border states , interests not held by any 
other commenters . This proceeding will affect a number of CURE ’s particular  interests and efforts .  
First,  ALLETE’s sale (including to Minnesota Power) will impact the ability of rural 
Minnesotans to engage with the ownership and direction of their electric utility , a core area of work 
for CURE . Converting ownership of Minnesota Power to foreign and private equity investment will 
cloud much of the public information that is now available to ratepayers and will potentially 
hamstring efforts to increase accountability and transparency of Minnesota  Power’s efforts  to 
decarbonize or failure to do so .  
3 
 Second, recent environmental harms from a 5 -million -gallon ash spill at the Boswell coal 
plant  illustrate that Minnesota Power will need more, not less, investment in toxic waste 
management going forward.1 CURE’s focus on clean water policy in rural parts of Minnesota informs 
our work on assuring there is adequate investment in protecting water resources  from industrial 
discharges and spills. The conversion of ownership to private equity will have impacts on the future 
company ’s abilit y to pay for and mitigate such harms .  
Finally, the change in ownership of Minnesota Power to include a significant ownership 
stake by entities who already own resource extraction companies, including large stakes in 
Minnesota Power customers Cleavland Cliffs and U.S. Steel, demonstrates a potential for a conflict 
of interest . CURE has serious concerns that large customers already have too much control over 
Minnesota Power’s operations . Aligning ownership between these ratepayers and Minnesota Power 
would likely leave regular ratepayers with large rate increases that support the doubled profits of 
the utility’s private equity owners. CURE is also concerned that foreign resource -extraction 
interests, once they have control of Minnesota Power, will favor  polluting fossil -fueled energy 
sources despite the availability of cheaper renewable energy options.  
Given the potential for significant impacts on CURE’s unique interests , CURE  wishes to join 
as a named party. As an intervenor, CURE would  contribute to the development of the factual and 
legal record in the docket , including but not limited to submission of testimony, cross -examination 
of witnesses, and the filing of briefs . This petition is timely and will not prejudice any party to these

 proceedings.2 CURE  therefore  requests that i ts Petition to Intervene be granted and that it be 
accorded full  party status under Minn esota Rule 7829.2400, subpart 6 .
